messages.message: @Handsome Dave I noticed you bumped open-cv to 4.1.0.25 when you updated the dockerfiles -- was that intentional?
i think the API has changes that break existing code
This was the python 3 updates?
(Sorry, just trying to remember)
https://github.com/instabase/instabase/pull/10698/files
yea and i realized i approved it haha but i missed the package upgrade
I’m looking into it. I have vague memories of some stuff being deprecated, but I don’t recall exactly.

ok we need to align all the various opencv versions:
```
data-services/doc-services/docops-service/Dockerfile:RUN pip install --user opencv-contrib-python==3.4.0.12
data-services/ocr-services/ocr-emerson/Dockerfile.build:  && pip install --user opencv-python==4.1.0.25 \
distributed-tasks/celery/app-tasks/Dockerfile:  pip install --user opencv-python-headless==4.1.0.25 && \
distributed-tasks/celery/app-tasks/Dockerfile:  pip install --user opencv-contrib-python-headless==4.1.0.25 && \
distributed-tasks/celery/image-tasks/Dockerfile:  pip install --user opencv-python-headless==4.1.0.25 && \
distributed-tasks/celery/image-tasks/Dockerfile:  pip install --user opencv-contrib-python-headless==4.1.0.25 && \
distributed-tasks/celery/webdriver-tasks/Dockerfile:  pip install --user opencv-contrib-python==3.4.0.12 && \
distributed-tasks/celery/webdriver-tasks/Dockerfile:  pip install --user opencv-python==3.3.0.10 && \
experimental/ted/checkbox/find/find_checkbox.ipynb:    "  if len(opencv_image.shape) == 3:\n",
shared-utils/py-utils/docops-lib/src/py/instabase/docops_lib/constellation/constellation.py:    if alignment_algorithm == 'opencv:homographic':
shared-utils/py-utils/image-utils/src/py/instabase/image_utils/file_io.py:  if len(opencv_image.shape) == 3:
tools/devtools/code-dependencies/py_licenses.csv:Python,opencv-contrib-python==3.4.0.12,MIT
tools/devtools/code-dependencies/py_licenses.csv:Python,opencv-python==3.3.0.10,MIT
tools/devtools/code-dependencies/python/requirements.txt: opencv-contrib-python==3.4.0.12
tools/devtools/code-dependencies/python/requirements.txt: opencv-python==3.3.0.10
tools/devtools/code-dependencies/python/requirements_py3.txt: opencv-contrib-python==3.4.0.12
tools/devtools/code-dependencies/python/requirements_py3.txt: opencv-python==3.3.0.10
webserver/api-server-apps/Dockerfile:    pip install --user opencv-python-headless==4.1.0.25 && \
```
*That* might have been it, actually. That other places we were using 4.1.0.25, so I thought I was ok to make it the same where I was touching?
Which is obviously, in hindsight, not brilliant. :upside_down_face:
yea i'm a bit concerned what else might break
opencv also seems a bit lax on listing all its breaking changes in their changelog

There was something else that made me look at updating in the first place (there are lots of deps that are “outdated” that I didn’t touch). It may have been an issue with the 3.x version compiling with python 3.6? I just can’t remember why I would have been looking at that particular module to begin with.
That at least sounds plausible to me, that there was a py3 issue with the older version, then I saw we were using the newer version elsewhere and just “copied” the dep over.
can you find that issue?
in the meantime i'm going to switch everything back to 3.4.0
I’ll dig into it, yeah.
What errors were you seeing, btw?
the API changed for calls like cv2.findContours
in general when bumping versions, we have to read the changelogs for any API changes, especially when updating major versions
it's always a bit of a bumpy process, but ideally if we also had updated it in our devtools requirements.txt, travis would have caught it in unit tests
Yeah, I’m feeling pretty foolish, tbh. This isn’t my first major-library-version-upgrade-rodeo :confused:
no worries - i totally missed it as well
this is also why I want to help streamline our python module management, because with our current setup, it's super easy to create this kind of version skew
ideally, the code module (e.g. the shared python util using cv2) would specify the version. and if two modules use different versions, it should complain at build time
and this way, when you bump versions, it's closer to the code where it's used. so hopefully harder to mess up
Found it!
The problem that I was looking into is that, when building opencv-3.x with python 3.6 (and this isn’t the case with 2.x for some reason) it doesn’t install the “headless” version.
what do you mean?

So when you try to run it, you’ll get this error:
```
ImportError: libSM.so.6: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```
which, iirc, is eventually fixed by installing a bunch of X11 libraries.
weird i just tried pip installing it and it seems fine?
Whereas the opencv 4.x line has an explicit “headless” version in pip to install that bypasses that entirely.
It pip installs but it doesn’t actually run.
oh interesting
should we just switch to not headless for now then?

This is the full output of a `docker run` when built with USE_PY3=true:
```
docker run  --name instabase-worker-image-tasks --env-file /Users/dbishop/workspace/instabase/distributed-tasks/celery/image-tasks/tmp/docker_env_local.list \
	-P --rm -t -i instabase/worker-image-tasks
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/ibuser/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/celery/app/utils.py", line 359, in find_app
    sym = symbol_by_name(app, imp=imp)
  File "/home/ibuser/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/celery/bin/base.py", line 504, in symbol_by_name
    return imports.symbol_by_name(name, imp=imp)
  File "/home/ibuser/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/kombu/utils/imports.py", line 61, in symbol_by_name
    return getattr(module, cls_name) if cls_name else module
AttributeError: module 'instabase.registry' has no attribute 'tasks'

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/ibuser/.local/bin/celery", line 10, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/home/ibuser/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/celery/__main__.py", line 16, in main
    _main()
  File "/home/ibuser/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/celery/bin/celery.py", line 322, in main
    cmd.execute_from_commandline(argv)
  File "/home/ibuser/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/celery/bin/celery.py", line 496, in execute_from_commandline
    super(CeleryCommand, self).execute_from_commandline(argv)))
  File "/home/ibuser/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/celery/bin/base.py", line 273, in execute_from_commandline
    argv = self.setup_app_from_commandline(argv)
  File "/home/ibuser/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/celery/bin/base.py", line 479, in setup_app_from_commandline
    self.app (http://self.app) = self.find_app(app)
  File "/home/ibuser/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/celery/bin/base.py", line 501, in find_app
    return find_app(app, symbol_by_name=self.symbol_by_name)
  File "/home/ibuser/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/celery/app/utils.py", line 362, in find_app
    sym = imp(app)
  File "/home/ibuser/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/celery/utils/imports.py", line 104, in import_from_cwd
    return imp(module, package=package)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/importlib/__init__.py", line 126, in import_module
    return _bootstrap._gcd_import(name[level:], package, level)
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 994, in _gcd_import
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 971, in _find_and_load
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 955, in _find_and_load_unlocked
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 665, in _load_unlocked
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap_external>", line 678, in exec_module
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 219, in _call_with_frames_removed
  File "/instabase/workers/celery-image-tasks/py/instabase/registry/tasks.py", line 17, in <module>
    import cv2
  File "/home/ibuser/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cv2/__init__.py", line 9, in <module>
    from .cv2 import *
ImportError: libSM.so.6: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```
So I can absolutely make this work with opencv 3.x, I’ll just need to re-figure out all the underlying library deps and install them when we build it with py3.
how do i run a docker as py3?
`make USE_PY3=true build-docker && make run-docker`
ah ok -- are the resulting docker images different if you have use_py3 vs not?
oh i guess yea cause it has a different base image right?
Yeah
for now should i switch from headless back to desktop? i just need to fix it for this UAT
and then you can work on updating the dockerfiles with the right libraries for headless next week?
If you give me ~10 minutes, I can have a version of the dockerfile that works for python 2 and 3, with opencv 3.x.
Kk
https://github.com/instabase/instabase/pull/10924
ten, twenty seven. You say tomato…
awesome! commented. can you make the same changes to api-server-apps and app-tasks as well? because we import the same pyutils into all our services, it won't work if they have different versions
btw did you not want to use headless anymore?
i'm actually ok with that because our travis/jenkins image requirements.txt isn't using headless. whatever we update, we should update that as well
I was just reverting to what was there before.
ocr-emerson is still on 4.0 but it sounds like it might need it so we leave that for now
i think we should fix the version skew because i'm sure it'll cause additional problems. i can add it to your PR

The earliest release of opencv-contrib-python-headless is 3.4.0.14, which is 0.0.0.2 newer than what we were using. I’m happy to bump up to it (if they have a backwards-incompatible change in a 0.0.0.2 bump, I’ll happy drive to their house and yell at them), but if we want to stick with exactly 3.4.0.12 then I’ll have to not use headless.
let's keep it without headless since that's what we have for the jenkin/travis image
how do you feel about fixing the version for api-server-apps and app-tasks as well?
Yup, doing that now.
Wait, so are we bumping the requirements.txt to 3.4.0.12? Or leaving it at 3.3.0.10?
i think the requirements.txt has opencv-contrib-python at 3.4.0.12 and opencv-python at 3.3.0.10, so exactly what you have in the PR
why they are different i have no idea :disappointed:
there's definitely follow-up work to be done here
i just want to cherry-pick the minimum amount of changes for UAT though
Yeah
actually i wonder if that just means we're actually on 3.3.0 because i assume pip uses the latest? not sure how that works when 2 modules override the same namespace
last one applied wins :slightly_smiling_face:
Which in requirements.txt was the 3.3 base version, but in the dockerfiles it was the 3.4 contrib module.
“yay”
@Handsome Dave this PR looks good to me. I'm just building the dockers now so I can confirm that the issue I ran into is fixed
Good deal. Sorry for the trouble and I’ll be more careful going forward.
thank you!
Let me know when to merge (or you can merge it, either way)
approved! and i merged
i'll cherry pick the pr into the release branch
